The effective date of the new export restrictions on rare-earth metals and refining equipment, marking when foreign companies must begin complying with the new licensing requirements.
The estimated date of Trump's visit to South Korea for the APEC summit, where he is expected to meet President Xi Jinping, placing the new controls in a high-stakes diplomatic context.

keyTakeAways: China has expanded its export controls on rare-earth metals, now restricting 12 out of the 17 known rare-earth elements.

The new restrictions apply to five additional metals: holmium, erbium, thulium, europium, and ytterbium, bringing the total to 12 restricted metals (7 previously announced in April 2025, plus 5 new ones).
China also restricted the export of specialized technological equipment used to refine rare-earth metals, effective December 1, 2025.
Foreign companies must obtain special approvals from Beijing to export rare-earth magnets and semiconductor materials containing at least 0.1% heavy rare-earth metals.
China justified the controls on national security grounds, citing dual-use applications of rare-earth metals in both civilian and military technologies.
The US is the largest importer of Chinese rare-earth products, having imported $22.8 million worth in 2023, with 70% of its rare-earth imports originating from China between 2020 and 2023.
Rare-earth metals are critical for advanced defence systems (e.g., F-35 jets, submarines, missiles, radar) and civilian technologies (e.g., electric vehicles, smartphones, medical imaging).
China is the world’s largest producer and processor of rare-earth metals, mining at least 60% and processing about 90% of global supply.
This move is seen as a strategic signal of leverage ahead of the Trump–Xi meeting at APEC, indicating China's intent to use supply chain dominance as a diplomatic tool.
Analysts suggest the restrictions deepen the US defence and industrial vulnerability, widening capability gaps and undermining US efforts to bolster domestic critical mineral supply chains.
China stated that emergency medical needs, public health emergencies, and disaster relief exports will be exempt from restrictions.

summaryOfNewsArticle: China has expanded its export controls on rare-earth metals, adding five new metals—holmium, erbium, thulium, europium, and ytterbium—to its list of restricted elements, bringing the total to 12 out of 17 rare-earth metals. The restrictions, announced by the Ministry of Commerce, will take effect on December 1, 2025, and apply to both the export of metals and specialized refining equipment. Foreign companies must obtain special approvals from Beijing, detailing the intended use of products containing at least 0.1% heavy rare-earth metals. China justifies these actions on national security grounds, citing concerns over foreign entities using Chinese rare-earth materials for military applications. The move comes just before the APEC summit in South Korea, where US President Donald Trump is expected to meet Chinese President Xi Jinping, suggesting it is a strategic signal to strengthen China’s leverage in upcoming trade negotiations. The US, the largest importer of Chinese rare-earth products, faces significant disruption in defence and civilian technology sectors, including fighter jets, submarines, missiles, and electric vehicles. Analysts argue that the restrictions deepen the US's technological and industrial vulnerabilities, while reinforcing China’s dominant position in the global rare-earth supply chain.
title: China tightens export controls on rare-earth metals: Why this matters
